Games Inbox: Quantum Break launch day, God Of War 4’s Kratos, and Dark Souls invaders

GameCentral for Metro.co.ukTuesday 5 Apr 2016 6:04 pm

The evening Inbox looks forward to E3 2016’s new controversies, as one reader thinks Oculus Rift and Vive might be flops.

To join in with the discussions yourself email gamecentral@ukmetro.co.uk

 

Dead on arrival

Although I’m sure the bad reviews are perfectly valid, does anyone worry that Quantum Break is going to kill Remedy? I don’t get the impression any of their games are that successful, and being an Xbox One exclusive I imagine Quantum Break is going to be pretty much a flop straight out of the gate. Where do they go from there? I know Phil Spencer is a fan, but he’s not a fool and I severely doubt the game is going to get a sequel based on things at this stage.

Looking back at it now I get the feeling that all the talk about Alan Wake Easter eggs and the like was a bit of a desperate attempt to make people want to look forwards to what came next, almost as if Quantum Break was being ditched straight away. Maybe it wasn’t quite like that, but it can’t be good to work on a game for that long and know it’s basically dead on arrival.
Tim Powers
PS: Is a sequel hinted at in the ending, GC?

GC: Very much so, or at least story DLC.

 

Worldwide surplus

I’m okay with God Of War 4 being based on Norse mythology. My main concern is that it has nothing to do with Kratos, who I can’t stand as a main character and ruins the games for me. But, after the letter yesterday about Uncharted and Sony exclusives I do wonder whether God Of War is really even a thing worth carrying on with.

Even though it’s newer than that it feels very 90s, with its angry male lead, ultra-violence, and casual sexism. The whole thing has run out of steam as far as I’m concerned and personally I’d rather Sony just got on with something new, rather than dragging out a couple more sequels. Mind you I feel that way about most of their games to be honest (and Microsoft’s).

There’s only so many Uncharted, Gears Of War, Halo, and Killzone games the world needs and I strongly feel this generation hasn’t seen nearly enough new franchises yet. And if these upgrade consoles are real maybe it never will.
Josh

 

Last mover advantage

This E3 is going to be a bloodbath at this rate. I can’t wait. You’ve got Sony, Microsoft, and Nintendo all about to show off new consoles and each has got to explain and justify why they’re coming out so soon after their last one. And consider how often games companies put their foot in it you just know they’re going to mess it up.

I do wonder whether Microsoft is going to try and do something about having to ‘go first’ with their press conference though. Like many I bet Sony changed their plans at the last minute in 2014, making Microsoft look like the villains with their always-on and DRM plans. I’d bet anything Sony were going to do the same thing but had time to change their presentation and pretend otherwise.

I mean, they did reference Microsoft’s event in theirs, so it’s not as if they weren’t watching it. Not that I care, it just makes for good theatre. Roll on with this year’s circus!
Smiler

 

E-mail your comments to: gamecentral@ukmetro.co.uk

 

Console reality

I too think that consoles are going to end up being the main market for virtual reality. In fact I’m now beginning to get the impression that Oculus Rift and HTC Vive are going to be kind of flops. They’re just too expensive, especially when you factor in the price of the PC you need to play them. And even more so when you figure there’ll be a better model out next year, and the year after that, and so on.

The PlayStation VR isn’t exactly cheap but I think Sony are sensible enough to realise it should be a one shot deal (even if that’s no longer the case with their consoles). More importantly Sony have a much better angle on getting more proper games released for their VR. I still don’t even know what actual proper games I’m supposed to be looking forward to on either console.

Even Valve’s The Lab is just a mini-game collection. I can see it being a long time before there’s an affordable killer app and by then it may be too late.
Shipton

 

Perfect snowflake

I see you criticised The Division for not enough movable stuff. I was standing outside the base and could see individual snowflakes, we shot paint cans and they had different colours in them. Love it such a detailed world, it does indeed make Destiny look like Defiance. Loving it, the guns feel so solid, it’s an amazing feat to have such a detailed world.

Dark Souls III next week, we’ve never had it do good. Look back to Pong, how far gaming has come.
Zombiekicker (PSN ID)

 

Cave of treasures

RE: Big Lizafish. As GC stated, most of Cave’s best 2D shooters are on iOS and play like a dream. Espgaluda II HD is my personal favourite but DonDonPachi Resurrection and Deathsmiles are both damn fine and have lite (demo) versions to try out.

More Cave games include DonDonPachi Blissful Death and Bug Princess 1 and 2. And I recommend trying out Space Invaders Infinity and Air Attack 2.
Chaosphere616 (gamertag)
Currently playing: Dariusburst (Vita/PSTV)

 

No disintegrations

On the subject of quitting if you are invaded in a Souls game. When I played Dark Souls I would always run away or commit suicide if someone invaded. The reason is due to a story I read about Demon’s Souls where ‘griefers’ would not just kill you but disintegrate all your equipment and leave you with nothing.

I am not even sure if that was true in Demon’s Souls or if it is even possible in Dark Souls but I was not taking any chances. Killing me and setting me back 10 minutes is fine, destroying 20+ hours of progress however is not.
PazJohnMitch

GC: It’s not true. Although in Demon’s Souls there was a weapon that could break your equipment, forcing you to repair it.

 

Catch up on every previous Games Inbox here

 

Run the gauntlet

It’s nice to see a positive response to the weekend Reader’s Feature about invasions in Dark Souls, but I would like to offer my own dissenting opinion.

I didn’t have as much as a problem with invasions in Dark Souls as I did in Dark Souls II – particularly at the dragon sanctuary leading up to the ancient dragon, or in the hall in Drangleic Castle.

I couldn’t do much about the latter, often getting destroyed by five ruin sentinels, eight animate statues, and whomever decided to annoy me at that moment in time.

For the former I eventually got fed up – the gauntlet to the boss was sometimes tough, so being defeated at the end by an invader meant trying to run the gauntlet again, often losing a large number of souls and some humanity. So to prevent further headaches I would systematically clear the area, repeatedly, until no more enemies would respawn.

While doing so I would sometimes be invaded, so to make the invader feel as frustrated as I was, I would lead them to the cliff-side near the bonfire, sometimes waiting for a good five minutes, and then leap to my death before they can land a single hit on me.

Since I died close to the bonfire, nothing of value was lost, and I got some satisfaction due to the schadenfraude.

I was never good at the player vs. player, and since it’s actually completely unnecessary to complete the game I neither see the point in invading, nor do I feel duty bound to humour those who decide to impede my progress and enjoyment of the game.
Joseph Dowland

 

Inbox also-rans

That Trump story is just… what? I know they say truth is stranger than fiction. But having a real politician that’s more comically evil (and stupid) than a video game boss is just scary.
The Colt

Just one comment on the Batman v Superman movie. Did anyone notice that the dream world explanation and Flash’s warning is basically the same set-up as Injustice?
ProPot

 

This week’s Hot Topic

The subject for this weekend’s Inbox was suggested by reader Grackle, who asks: how much attention do you pay to reviews?

When anticipating a new game do you wait for the reviews to come out first, or do you ignore them? Do you have particular sources you always trust or do you put more stock into aggregators such as Metacritic? How important do you think a score is and have you ever got embroiled in arguments over them?

What’s your routine for dealing with reviews? Do you avoid them before a game is released and come back to them later, or do you just read the highlights on Metacritic? What do you enjoy and not enjoy most about reviews and how would you like them to change in the future?

E-mail your comments to: gamecentral@ukmetro.co.uk

 

The small print
New Inbox updates appear twice daily, every weekday morning and afternoon. Letters are used on merit and may be edited for length.

You can also submit your own 500 to 600-word 4Player viewer features at any time, which if used will be shown in the next available weekend slot.

If you need quick access to the GameCentral channel page please use www.metro.co.uk/games and don’t forget to follow us on Twitter.
